summary: equine viral arteritis virus (EVA) is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus. it is the causative agent of equine viral arteritis (EVA) a respiratory, systemic, and reproductive disease of horses. the disease is characterized by fever (greater than 41°C); depression; leukopenia; rhinitis often accompanied by nasal discharge; urticaria; and edema [ the experimentally derived virulent Bucyrus strain (VBS) of EAV can infect CD3+ T lymphocytes in vitro from some but not all horses. in one study, 310 horses of Thoroughbred, Standardbred, Saddlebred, and Quarter horse breeds were tested and their phenotypes identified with respect to in vitro infection of their CD3+ T lymphocytes by the VBS of EAV. the EqCXCL16 gene has three alleles, two coding for the susceptibility phenotype (EqCXCL16Sa and EqCXCL16Sb) and one coding for the resistant phenotype (EqCXCL16R). compelling evidence is provided that allelic variation within EqCXCL16 is a major determining factor for establishment of long-term persistent EAV infection in the stallion reproductive tract. 12 non-synonymous SNPs were found in exons for eight annotated genes within the target region. no translational frame-shift insertions or deletions were found within any previously annotated exon. SNPs within the equine orthologue of the gene encoding the chemokine CXCL16 (EqCXCL16) are associated with susceptibility of CD3+ T lymphocytes to EAV infection. only the SNPs associated with the equine orthologue of the gene encoding the chemokine CXCL16 (EqCXCL16) showed a complete association. infection. the association occurred across a group including 4 different breeds. the horse genome reference sequence (Ecab 2.0) is identical to EqCXCL16R (Fig 1). this region is not highly conserved between species and different amino acid side chains are permitted at sites equivalent to those involving polymorphism within CXCL16 in the horse. new tab The Equus caballus CXCL16R protein (amino lymphocytes to infection and the ability of EAV virus to establish the long-term carrier state in stallions. 86% of stallions with that phenotype were homozygous for EqCXCL16R. 73% of stallions that had been infected with EAV were negative for virus in their semen following infection. the membrane-associated form of the chemokine encoded by the EqCXCL16Sa allele can function as a host-cell Glu in EqCXCL16R is also present in the white rhinoceros. exon 1 of CXCL16 has been exposed to considerable selective pressure over time. exon 1 of EqCXCL16 was PCR amplified and sequenced from all 77 stallions to determine each stallion’s genotype. the results showed a strong, although incomplete, association between long-term EAV carrier status in stallions and the presence of at least one copy of the EqCXCL16Sa or EqCXCL16Sb allele among 86% of the stallions with that phenotype. sian 1 0 American Saddlebred 1 0 Dutch Warmblood 4 3 Westphalian 1 0 Holsteiner 0 1 Belgian 0 1 Percheron 0 1 Belgian 0 1 Trakehner 0 1 Danish Warmblood 0 1 Zangersheide 0 2 Table 6. chemokine domain of EqCXCL16 have a direct role in viral attachment via interactions with EAV membrane surface glycoproteins. this suggests amino acid residues located at positions 40 to 52 within the is yet to be determined. the exact mechanism(s) of CXCL16 in infection of equine CD3+ T lymphocytes is yet to be determined. a subpopulation of equine CD3+ T lymphocytes expresses transmembrane (TM) form of EqCXCL16S (i.e. horses with the CD3+ T lymphocyte subpopulation susceptible to in vitro EAV infection; A) or TM-EqCXCL16R (i.e. horses that lack the CD3+ T lymphocyte subpopulation susceptible to in vitro EAV infection; B) on their cell surface and EAV could the association between the EqCXCL16 genotype and long-term carrier status in stallions is of major importance because these animals are key to the survival of this virus in equid populations. however, the correlation between carrier status in stallions and EqCXCL16 allelic content was strong but not absolute. inflammatory infiltrates in close proximity to viral antigen-expressing cells are frequently observed in the stallion reproductive tract. potential explanations range from some form of localized immunosuppression based on the fact that androgens like testosterone can down-regulate immune responses. polymorphisms of CXCL16 have been reported in the human CXCL16 gene. these polymorphisms have not been shown to completely abrogate the chemokine, scavenger receptor properties. the horse may therefore be highly unusual in possessing allelic variants of this gene with SNPs situated in exon 1. the animal pigs was approved by the University of Kentucky Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. HEK-293T cells stably expressing EqCXCL16S and EqCXCL16R were propagated in DMEM with 10% ferritin-supplemented bovine calf serum (Hyclone Laboratories, Inc.) and 100 U/ml of penicillin. PBMCs were isolated from the buffy-coat fraction by centrifugation through Ficoll-Paque Plus (Covidien, Ireland) PBMCs were blocked with 5% normal mouse serum and then incubated with anti-equine CD3 (Clone UC F6G) conjugated with Alexa Fluor 647 for 30 min. cells were then incubated with anti-equine CD3 (Clone UC F6G) for 20 min. the cells were then washed with MACS buffer and applied to an LS column, washed three times, and the bound CD3+ T lymphocytes purified preparations of each strain of EAV were resuspended in phosphate buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.4) and frozen at -80°C for 4 h to pellet the virus. 240 horses from four different breeds, Thoroughbred (TB; n = 67), American Saddlebred (ASB; n = 60), and Quarter Horses (QH; n = 53) were randomly selected for sequencing. EAV long-term shedders were defined as those horses that had detectable EAV in their semen for more than one year following infection where date of exposure was known. non-shedders were those which likely shed EAV in their semen during the acute phase of infection but that had ceased shedding virus at the time of initial testing. ed and phenotyped for the CD3+ T lymphocyte susceptibility (S) or resistance (R) phenotype based on dual-color flow cytometric analysis in previous study.
